title: Fluidity in the Medieval Aristotle. Readers and Readings of the Greek-Latin Translations
descriptions:
The grant proposal "Fluidity in the Medieval Aristotle: Readers and Readings of the Greek-Latin Translations" seeks to delve into the impact areas of philosophy, science, and theology within the late medieval and early modern periods. With a focus on hundreds of manuscripts containing Latin translations of Aristotle from the 12th and 13th centuries, the main goal is to conduct a comprehensive investigation into new ways of interpreting the Latin Aristotle. By examining textual variances in handwritten books that preserve these translations, the project aims to document variant readings in manuscript witnesses, particularly in treatises such as "De anima," "De generatione et corruptione," and "De caelo."

The significance of this research lies in uncovering the textual fluidity present in these manuscripts, shedding light on how readers engaged with these translations that differed from the original Greek texts. The project's innovation lies in developing a new model of interpretation for medieval translations of philosophy and science, pushing the boundaries of scholarship in this area. This study will provide valuable insights into the intellectual climate of the time and contribute to a deeper understanding of the transmission and reception of knowledge in the medieval period.

This grant proposal seeks to investigate the fluidity in the Medieval Aristotle through a comprehensive examination of readers and readings of Greek-Latin translations. By documenting variant readings in these manuscript witnesses, the study aims to shed light on the textual variance present in handwritten books preserving translations.

The main goal of this research is to develop new ways to read the Latin Aristotle and to create a model of interpretation for medieval translations of philosophy and science. By exploring the impact of textual fluidity on readers' engagement with these translations, the project will contribute to our understanding of how these texts were received and interpreted in their historical context.

Through its focus on textual fluidity and the development of critical editions of key treatises, this project promises to advance scholarship in philosophy, science, and theology. By uncovering the ways in which readers were exposed to and engaged with these translations, the research will provide valuable insights into the reception of Greek philosophy in the medieval period and its influence on subsequent intellectual developments.

This grant proposal, titled "Fluidity in the Medieval Aristotle: Readers and Readings of the Greek-Latin Translations," seeks to explore the impact of textual variance in handwritten books preserving translations of Aristotle's works during the late medieval and early modern periods. This study not only contributes to the fields of philosophy, science, and theology but also offers a unique perspective on the transmission and reception of knowledge in the medieval period. Through this exploration of textual fluidity, the project aims to deepen our understanding of the intellectual history of the era and the ways in which these translations shaped the development of thought in the medieval and early modern periods.
